Cavitation Constraints

The minimum pressure coefficient (\(C_{p,\text{min}}\)) corresponds to the lowest pressure on the blade, typically near the leading edge or suction side, where velocity is highest due to Bernoulli’s principle. It is defined as:

\[C_{p,\text{min}} = \frac{P - P_\infty}{\frac{1}{2} \rho V_\infty^2}\]

Here, \(P\) is the local pressure on the blade surface, \(P_\infty\) is the freestream pressure, \(\rho\) is the fluid density, and \(V_\infty\) is the effective velocity at the blade tip. The effective velocity is calculated as:

\[V_\infty = \sqrt{U_{\text{inf\_adjusted}}^2 + (r \cdot \omega)^2}\]

where \(U_{\text{inf\_adjusted}}\) is the adjusted flow speed, \(r\) is the rotor radius, and \(\omega\) is the rotational speed of the rotor.

To avoid cavitation, the pressure at the blade surface must remain above the vapor pressure of water:

\[P_{\text{min}} > P_{\text{vapor}}\]

Using the pressure equation:

\[P = P_{\text{atm}} + \rho g h\]

where \(P_{\text{atm}}\) is the atmospheric pressure, \(\rho g h\) is the hydrostatic pressure due to the depth of the turbine below the water surface, and \(h\) is the depth. The depth \(h\) is calculated as:

\[h = d - r\]

Here, \(d\) is the hub depth (distance from the water surface to the hub of the rotor), and \(r\) is the rotor radius. This accounts for the fact that the blade tip is located at a depth \(d - r\), which is above than the hub depth.

Substituting \(h = d - r\) into the cavitation condition gives:

\[P_{\text{atm}} + \rho g (d - r) + \frac{1}{2} \rho V_\infty^2 C_{p,\text{min}} > P_{\text{vapor}}\]

To express the cavitation constraint in Python’s standard inequality format (\(h(x) \geq 0\)), the equation is rearranged as:

\[h(x) = P_{\text{atm}} + \rho g (d - r) + \frac{1}{2} \rho V_\infty^2 C_{p,\text{min}} - P_{\text{vapor}}\]

Here, \(h(x)\) is the cavitation constraint function, which must satisfy \(h(x) \geq 0\) to ensure no cavitation occurs. If \(h(x) < 0\), cavitation occurs, as the pressure at the blade surface drops below the vapor pressure.
